author: @DonatasStaneika
text: Another tip: when you list your previous jobs, list as many job tasks related to data analytics as possible. For example, if you worked as a cashier, you could list that you worked with numbers and had to pay attention to detail (kinda like data cleaning). I did Google Data Analytics Certificate a couple of months ago and landed a job as a junior data analyst at a solid company with no previous experience. I have BC in Philosophy and MA in Public policy, and my experience was pretty much project management at NGOs. Alex is completely right, learning skills is the most important part (and honestly learning only Excel, SQL and Tableau is enough and not that hard). Good luck everyone.

author: @hasibahmad3660
text: My question is what if I have those technical skills but I am not good at statistics or I am unable to connnect the dots. By saying this I meant for example I know how to calculate mean, median and mode using python or excel but I don't know when to use what... I know how to calculate outliers but how to get insight from it and determine if I should ignore the outliers or not. These problems are I am facing now. Sometimes, I learn statistics and when I come back to learn python, I feel like I start to forget those statistical concepts that I have learned so far. How to get rid of these situation?
